questions.text: A patient presents with nail changes as shown in the image. Which of the following cannot be used in the treatment?
questions.solution:
Roughly one half of the psoriasis patients suffer from nail changes. Over lifetime, up to 90% of all psoriatics will have had nail alterations. The prevalence of nail psoriasis is even higher in psoriatic arthritis

Pits are the most common signs. Classically, CID – Coarse, Irregular, Deep pits

They are the result of tiny psoriatic foci of parakeratosis in the matrix.

Ten pits in one nail or >50 pits on all nails are regarded as proof of psoriasis

Salmon or oil spots are most specific finding and represent psoriatic plaques in the most distal matrix and the nail bed.

Other findings : Subungual hyperparakeratosis, Splinter hemorrhage, onycholysis

Treatment

Topical - Corticosteroids, Vitamin D3 analogs calcipotriol and tacalcitol, Tazarotene, Methotrexate

And Systemic treatments are indicated in widespread psoriasis.

Amorolfine is used in onychomycosis. May show similar findings of subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis but there is no pitting.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 147

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden onset multifocal patchy alopecia. The dermoscopic finding is shown in the image below. The contact allergens found to be beneficial in the treatment of this disease include following except-
questions.solution:
The history of sudden onset patchy alopecia along with classical exclamation mark hair sign seen on the dermoscopic image are highly suggestive of alopecia areata as the diagnosis.

Contact immunotherapy is well documented treatment for alopecia areata, especially in patients with chronic/multifocal/resistant lesions. The contact allergens that have been used in the treatment of alopecia areata include dinitrochlorobenzene (DNCB), squaric acid dibutylester (SADBE) and diphenylcyclopropenone (DPCP).

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1173

questions.text: A 25 year old male had arthritis in right ankle and skin lesions as shown. He also has fever and malaise for 2 weeks. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Erythema nodosum (EN) (red nodules) is an inflammation of the fat cells under the skin (panniculitis) characterized by tender red nodules or lumps that are usually seen on both shins.
  2. EN is an immunologic response to a variety of different causes.
  3. Crops of tender subcutaneous nodules, associated with fever/malaise/arthritis.
  4. Most common seen in Anterior surface of legs/Shins
  5. Resolve in 2-4 weeks, with post inflammatory hyperpigmentation
  6. Never ulcerate (contrast with posterior leg and ulceration seen in erythema induratum)

Seen with streptococcal infection(MC infectious association), TB, Sarcoidosis,

Drugs-OCP use, sulfonamides, Penicillin.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1734

choices.text: A hamartoma of eccrine sweat gland

questions.text: A 25 year old lady presented with asymptomatic lesions around the eye. What is the pathology of this disorder
questions.solution:
Syringoma is benign neoplasm with differentiation towards eccrine acrosyringium. Histologically ‘tadpole’ like morphology of tumour lobules present.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1944

questions.text: A 20 year old boy presents with asymptomatic skin lesions on the upper back. The results from a bedside test are shown below. Which of the following is given for the treatment -
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic skin lesions, with positive pale yellow fluorescence on woods lamp examination done in a dark room and the KOH scraping showing typical sphaghetti and meatball appearance is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor as the diagnosis.

Treatment

  1. Systemic azoles (ketoconazale, fluconazole or itraconazolE. provide a convenient therapeutic option.
  2. Topical antifungals are also effective; Azoles (clotrimazole, econazole, miconazole, ketoconazole, selenium sulfide, sodium thiosulfate, Whitefield’s ointment (3% salicylic acid + 6% Benzoic acid.
  3. Griseofulvin & terbinafine – No role in treatment of P. versicolor

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1332

questions.text: A 69 year old patient with long standing medical illness presented with skin lesions on shin. Which is the next investigation that you will do ?
questions.solution:
Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is asymptomatic.

Since it is seen ion long term diabetes, next investigation is blood sugar

Patients usually present with shiny, asymptomatic patches that slowly enlarge over months to years. The patches are initially red-brown and progress to yellow, depressed, atrophic plaques. Ulcerations can occur, typically after trauma and occasionally with associated pain. The patient's main complaint is the unsightly cosmetic appearance of the lesions.

Most cases of necrobiosis lipoidica occur on the pretibial area main findings on histopathology – granulomas, thickening of the blood vessel walls and endothelial cell swelling found in the middle to deep dermis, characteristics shared with diabetic microangiopathy.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1656

questions.text: A patient presented with lesions as shown in the image. Considering the treatment she will receive, which of the adverse effects of the drug needs to be monitoring ?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from nodulocystic acne

DOC – oral isotretinoin, 1 mg/kg/day; TCD – 120-150 mg/kg

A/E

Due to the well-known teratogenic effects of retinoic acid derivatives, negative pregnancy tests must be obtained prior to each prescription in females of reproductive age group and double contraceptives advised.

In addition, patients with a personal or family history of hypertriglyceridemia or a personal history of diabetes should be cautioned about the risks of hypertriglyceridemia and poor glucose control.

  1. Serum triglycerides should be followed during therapy.
  2. Concerns regarding a link between isotretinoin use and developing depression have not been proven.
  3. Wash out period of isotretinoin from fats is 1 months – gap between stopping drug and conception of baby.
  4. Pigmentation is a risk in those who receive minocycle while both mino and doxy can lead to photosenitivity.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 2212

questions.text: A 55 year old farmer, with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and hypertension, developed severe itchy rash on face, arms and legs. The most appropriate drug for his treatment would be -
questions.solution:
Treatment of Allergic contact dermatitis

  1. Topical corticosteroids in combination with oral antihistaminics are effective in most cases.
  2. Extensive contact dermatitis may require treatment with a short course of oral corticosteroids.
  3. In air-borne contact dermatitis, azathioprine may be effective, especially as a steroid sparing agent in patients with contraindications to steroid therapy

As corticosteroids are contraindicated in patients with DM and hypertension, best option here would be azathioprine.

Diagnosis: patch test, reading at 24 hr, 48 hr

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 242

questions.text: A patient gives a h/o recurrent oral ulcers as shown. He also has complains of blurred vision, periorbital pain and photophobia. The most likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
Behcet’s syndrome-Behcet’s syndrome is an disorder of unknown etiology having strong association with HLA B51.

Its more frequently seen in age group 20-30 years having male preponderance.

Clinical features-

Its characterized by recurrent oral and genital aphthous ulcers

Ulcers have a necrotic floor surrounded by halo of erythema.

Other features include erythema nodosum like lesions(which are deep seated multiple tender nodules on shin area)

pathergy test- used for diagnosis of Behcet’s syndrome.

Positive results from pathergy skin testing, defined as the formation of a sterile erythematous papule 2 mm in diameter or larger that appears 48 hours following a skin prick with a sharp sterile needle

Fixed drug eruption- these are characterized by well defined circular deeply erythematous plaques which sometimes develop central bullae. They subside leaving behind slate gray hyperpigmentation which persist btwn acute episodes. Lesions recur at same site each time the offending drug is taken usully after 8-16 hours after intake of drug. Drugs implicated - barbiturates, sulphonamides, tetracyclines, salicylates and phenacetin.

Herpes labialis- It is caused by HSV hominis type1.(HSV hominis has two antigenic types 1 and 2. Type 2 causes genital infection). HSV type1 infection is characterized by Acute gingivostomatitis(closely grouped vesicles which rapidly form polycyclic ulcers with a yellow psuedomembrane and heal in about a fortnight.). Malaise fever and lymphadenopathy are frequent.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 466

questions.text: A 25 year old young adult female presents with following lesions in axilla. The diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
1. The image shows presence of discrete skin colored dome shaped papules in the axilla just below the huge furuncle. The clinical diagnosis is Fox Fordyce disease.
  2. Hidradenitis suppurative presents with multiple blind boils with sinus tracts and recurrences in axilla, perineum and inguinal areas.
  3. Acne conglobata presents on face usually with nodulocystic acne and multiple interconnecting sinus tracts.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 647

questions.text: A dermatology referral was called for a newborn baby, image shown below. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Collodion baby refers to a newborn with a parchment-like membrane covering the entire body surface. The collodion baby is not a disease entity but phenotype common to several disorders. Collodion membrane at birth is gradually shed over 2 to 4 weeks usually revealing an ichthyosis phenotype.

A total of 60%-80% of children born with a collodion membrane eventually develop ichthyosis either nonbullous ichthyosiform erythroderma or lamellar ichthyosis

Rarer forms of congenital ichthyosis including trichothiodystrophy, gauchers disease, neutral lipid storage disease, Conradi-Hunermann disease, Sjogren- Larsson syndrome, and isolated palmoplantar keratoderma may be preceded by a collodion membrane.

Two most common types of skin disorders presenting as collodion at birth are non-bullous congenital erythroderma and Lamellar ichthyosis. Other less common pathologies responsible for this presentation include: Ectodermal dysplasia, Sjögren Larsen syndrome, Comel-Netherton syndrome Gaucher Disease type 2, Hay-Well syndrome, Trichothyodystrophy, Neutral lipid storage disease, etc.

Ichthyosis vulgaris- baby is normal at birth

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 901

questions.text: A 20 year old girl presents with recurrent episodes of swelling on the face associated with abdominal cramps. She has tried multiple over the counter medicines but no relief. Which of these can be used as a treatment?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is Hereditary angioneurotic edema (HAE), also called as Quincke disease.

Associated with mutation in SERPING1 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called C1 inhibitor.

Types I and II HAE are inherited as an autosomal dominant trait on chromosome 11q 12.1.

Type III HAE – Gain of function mutations of F12

All types of HAE are aggravated by Oestrogen in contraceptive and hormone replacement therapies

Treatment –

Agents used in the treatment of acute attacks of HAE include the following

C1-INH concentrate:

Kallikrein inhibitor – ecallantide

Selective bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist: Icatibant

Androgen analogues like danazol and tranexamic acid can be used for prophylaxis

Reference: MacGinnitie AJ, Campion M, Stolz LE, Pullman WE. Ecallantide for treatment of acute hereditary angioedema attacks: analysis of efficacy by patient characteristics. Allergy Asthma Proc. 2012 Mar-Apr;33(2):178-85. doi: 10.2500/aap.2012.33.3528. PMID: 22525395.

questions.text: All are true regarding the disease shown in the image except
questions.solution:
Histopathology of wart:

Histopathologic features include acanthosis, digitated epidermal hyperplasia, papillomatosis, compact orthokeratosis, hypergranulosis, tortuous capillaries within the dermal papillae and vertical tiers of parakeratotic cells with red blood cells entrapped above the tips of the digitations. Elongated rete ridges may point radially toward the center of the lesion. In the granular layer, cells infected with HPV have coarse keratohyalin granules and vacuoles surrounding wrinkled-appearing nuclei. Koilocytic cells are pathognomonic.

Reference: Al Aboud AM, Nigam PK. Wart. [Updated 2023 Aug 14]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Jan. Available from:

https: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431047/

questions.text: A 5 years old girl presented with lesions on the face for the last 3 months. A skin biopsy was performed and the findings are shown below. What is the approach to treatment?
questions.solution:
Molluscum contagiosum virus causes characteristic skin lesions consisting of single or, more often, multiple, dome-shaped, pearly white umbilicated papules.

Molluscum contagiosum is a viral disease caused by a DNA poxvirus

The molluscum contagiosum virus may be inoculated along a line of minor skin trauma (eg, from shaving, scratching), resulting in lesions arranged in a linear pattern -pseudokoebners phenomena

In adults, molluscum contagiosum most commonly is a sexually transmitted disease and more severe in HIV infected patients or chemotherapy/transplant patients

In healthy patients, molluscum contagiosum is generally self-limited and heals spontaneously after several months. Individual lesions are seldom present for more than 2 months. Although treatment is not required, it may help to reduce autoinoculation or transmission to close contacts and improve clinical appearance.

cryotherapy or curettage of individual lesions is effective and well tolerated.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1444

choices.text: Mono benzone ether of hydroquinone is the main chemical cause.
Melanocytes present but melanin absent in the patch

questions.text: Which of these is true about the disorder shown in the image ?
questions.solution:
Common items from which synthetic leather-/rubber-related leucoderma has been reported are rain shoes, rubber slippers, synthetic leather wallets, watch straps,and rubber gloves. Almost all cases occur when the offending item is in tight apposition against the skin, and is kept there for prolonged periods leading to leaching of the offending chemical.

chemical is a known melanocytotoxic agent and depigmentation.

No melanocytes in the lesion.

The treatment of chemical leucoderma hinges upon the early recognition of the condition (which is usually easy) and cessation of use of products.

Difficult to treat, topical steroids may help but ultimately, surgical methods needed.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1140

questions.text: A patient presented with photosensitivity, painful blistering of skin, fragile skin and extra hairgrowth on the face and hands. Which of these drugs can be used for treatment ?
questions.solution:
1. Porphyria cutanea tarda is a group of disorders which are characterized by raised porphyrins in the plasma, urine and feces.
  2. Although it is usually acquired, it can also be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. When the disease is acquired, it is generally secondary to liver damage, most typically from alcohol abuse, dialysis
  3. Alcohol and estrogens may also precipitate autosomal dominant porphyria cutanea tarda.
  4. Patients typically have increased hair on the sides of the face and periorificial violaceous discolorations and blisters on the dorsum of the hands that leave scar after healing. (Wolverine facies)
  5. There is marked skin fragility in sun-exposed skin areas.
  6. Urine of these patients show a pink fluorescence under Wood's light.
  7. Patient should avoid alcohol and exposure to direct sun light.
  8. Venesection, the removal of 500 ml of blood every 2 weeks, results in remission - TOC
  9. Chloroquine – oral drug, acts as a systemic sunscreen and anti-inflammatory drug
  10. Patients with pseudo-porphyria secondary to dialysis are treated with erythropoietin in combination with venisection.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 781

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this asymptomatic lesion shown in the image below ?
questions.solution:
• Annular lesions with beaded papules on margins
  • Asymptomatic
  • Seen commonly in Diabetic patient

Palisading granuloma on HPE (most important)

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1650

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown in the image
questions.solution:
True isomorphic phenomena:

  • Lichen planus
  • Vitiligo
  • Psoriasis

Pseudo isomorphic phenomena:

  • Verruca (Warts)
  • Molluscum Contagiosum

Reference: Sanchez DP, Sonthalia S. Koebner Phenomenon. [Updated 2022 Nov 14]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2023 Jan. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK553108/

questions.text: A young male presented with Hypo anesthetic patch on right forearm. On examination a thickened nerve was palpable. Histopathology shows the following:
questions.solution:
Single hypopigmented anaesthetic lesion with nerve enlargement – hints towards tuberculoid leprosy.

Histopath shows well defined granuloma abutting the epidermis, with nerve destruction and presence of giant cells.

Confirms diagnosis of TT leprosy

Reference: IAL Textbook of leprosy, 2nd edition. Pg no. 136

choices.text: Giemsa stain of lymph node aspirate

questions.text: A 23-year-old male had unprotected sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker. Two weeks later, he developed a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans which exuded clear serum on pressure. The most appropriate diagnostic test is:
questions.solution:
The question is talking about a genital ulcer due to an unprotected intercourse

a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans which exuded clear serum on pressure - typical of primary syphilis.

Associated with bilateral painless inguinal lymphadenopathy

Most specific investigation for primary syphilis : Darkfield microscopy of ulcer discharge – motile spiral bacteria

TOC : Injection benzathine penicillin 2.4 mIU stat

Reference: V K Sharma, A Textbook of Sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS, 2nd edition. Pg no. 267

questions.text: A male child with history of atopy, presents with the following clinical features. Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows fine scales over the limbs, with sparing of flexures. Classical of Ichthyosis vulgaris

ichthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder first evident in early childhood.

It is the most common form of ichthyosis

It is often caused by altered profilaggrin expression leading to scaling and desquamation

Hereditary ichthyosis is also associated with atopy. The protein filaggrin is important in maintaining effective skin barrier function.

Although the skin in hereditary ichthyosis vulgaris looks and feels normal at birth, it gradually becomes rough and dry in early childhood. Scaling tends to be most prominent on the extensor surfaces of the extremities and absent on the flexor surfaces.

Many hereditary ichthyosis vulgaris patients have associated atopic manifestations (eg, asthma, eczema, hay fever).

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 893

questions.text: A 30 year old patient came with flaccid bullae which rupture easily on touch. The biopsy from the lesion is shown below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
history of flaccid bullae and intra-epidermal cleft in biopsy give us a hint of the disease being pemphigus. Now we have to chose between pemphigus vulgaris and foliaceous.



Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 506

questions.text: The following lesion appears on the cheek of a patient, suffering from recurrent bouts of bloody diarrhoea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. The image shows erythematous, edematous plaque in a patient with IBD diagnostic of Sweet syndrome.
  2. Sweet syndrome is febrile neutropenic dermatosis in patients with inflammatory, haematological, visceral malignancy or vaccination.
  3. It shows excellent response to systemic steroids and potassium iodide
  4. Pyoderma gangrenosum, another neutropenic disease is ruled out as it seen as an painful ulcer with well-defined violaceous margins.
  5. Erythema nodosum occurs in up to 15% of CD patient and 10% of UC patients and responds when treatment for bowel inflammation is given. The lesions are red, tender nodules are found on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, calves, thighs.
  6. Erythema marginatum is seen with rheumatic fever.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 456

questions.text: A patient on MBMDT presented with lesions as shown. What will be the approach to treatment ?
questions.solution:
The patient is a known case of leprosy on treatment. Such patients can be prone to develop leprosy reactions.

The image shows multiple red nodules over the shin.

Diagnosis : Erythema nodosum leprosum

Multiple, painful red nodules on face, limbs and trunk

Associated with fever, arthralgia, malaise

Systemic manifestations - neuritis, uveitis, hepatatitis, orchitis

Treatment – continue MBMDT and start prednisolone(TOC)

Other drugs – thalidomide, prednisolone, methotrexate, pentoxifylline, TNFalpha inhibitors

Reference: IAL Textbook of leprosy, 2nd edition. Pg no. 469

questions.text: A 68 year old male came with itchy tense bullae on urticarial base and in sometime, roof of the bullae settled down. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease.
  • Usually seen in the elderly.
  • Lesions typically consist of tense blisters on either normal-appearing or erythematous skin.
  • Usually distributed over the lower abdomen, groin, and flexor surface of the extremities.
  • Oral mucosal lesions are found in 10 to 40% of patients.
  • Pruritus may be severe.
  • As lesions evolve, tense blisters tend to rupture and be replaced by flaccid lesions or erosions with or without surmounting crust.
  • BP do not have an increased incidence of malignancy.
  • Investigations:
    • Biopsies of early lesional skin demonstrate subepidermal blisters.
    • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy of normal-appearing perilesional skin shows linear deposits of IgG- and/or C3 in the epidermal basement membrane.
    • In BP, circulating autoantibodies recognize 230- and 180-kDa hemidesmosome-associated proteins in basal keratinocytes [i.e., bullous pemphigoid antigen (BPAG)1 and BPAG2, respectively].
  • Rx:
    • The mainstay of treatment is systemic glucocorticoids.
    • Patients will usually respond to prednisone, 40 to 60 mg/d.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 512

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions as shown in the image. Scrapings from the lesions will show?
questions.solution:
Image - grouped vesicles on penis, suggestive of genital herpes

Smear (Tzank smear) made from base of vesicle - Multinucleate giant cells & acantholytic cells (Tzank cells). Herpes is a one of the causes of secondary acantholysis.

Treatment : Aciclovir 400 mg TDS x 7 days

Secondary attacks can happen as virus lies dormant in sacral ganglion

Reference: V K Sharma, A Textbook of Sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS, 2nd edition. Pg no 410

questions.text: This is a characteristic rash of which disease?
questions.solution:
Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy with characteristic cutaneous findings that occur in children and adults

Persons with dermatomyositis often present with skin disease as one of the initial manifestations,

  • characteristic, possibly pathognomonic cutaneous features: Heliotrope rash, Gottron papules
  • Characteristic but not pathognomonic features: violaceous erythema or in a photosensitive distribution, violaceous erythema on the extensor surfaces of hands and arms (Gottron sign), and periungual telengiectasi
  • Violaceous erythema involving the anterior chest is referred to as the “V-neck sign” whereas involvement of the upper back and shoulders is referred to as the “shawl sign” and lateral thigh(Holster sign)
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Muscle fatigue/weakness when climbing stairs, walking, rising from a seated position, combing hair, or reaching for items above shoulders

Serology

A positive antinuclear antibody (ANA)

Anti-Mi-2 antibodies are highly specific for dermatomyositis

Anti-Jo-1

Muscle enzyme levels are often abnormal

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 683

questions.text: A child presented with unilateral depigmented lesion on neck and chin associated with leucotrichia. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The midline demarcation, presence of leucotrichia(White hair) in the lesion favour a diagnosis of Segmental vitiligo

Segmental vitiligo is an uncommon form of localized vitiligo, characterized by dermatomal distribution. It is often unilateral and asymmetrical that never crosses the midline of body

In this form of the disease, depigmentation spots spread quickly in the affected dermatomes and then stop growing.

This type of vitiligo does not have an autoimmune pathogenesis.

So immunosuppressives don’t prove useful in it.

Nevus Depigmentosus - present at birth, size increases with age

Nevus anemicus - area of pallor, not depigmented, not have leucotrichia

Piebaldism - has a autosomal dominant inheritance, associated with white forelock of hair, not leucotrichia within the lesion

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1091

questions.text: A patient presented with erythematous plaques covering more than 50% body surface area. On examination, the following finding was observed. which is not used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Red scaly plaques + auspitz sign seen in the picture : diagnosis of psoriasis

Psoriasis is a chronic proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin. It is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales particularly over the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region

The exact etiology is unknown, but it is considered to be an autoimmune disease mediated by T lymphocytes

Certain drugs like chloroquine, lithium, beta-blockers, steroids, and NSAIDs can worsen psoriasis. Generally, summer improves psoriasis while winter aggravates it. Apart from above factors infections, psychological stress, alcohol, smoking, obesity, and hypocalcemia are other triggering factors for psoriasis

The pathophysiology of psoriasis involves infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which stimulate proliferation of keratinocytes. This dysregulation in keratinocyte turnover results in the formation of thick plaques.

Psoriasis is classified into two types. Type 1 psoriasis, which has a positive family history, starts before age 40 and is associated with HLA-Cw6; while type 2 psoriasis does not show a family history, presents after age 40, and is not associated with HLA-Cw6.

Treatment :

Topical therapy is used in mild to moderate psoriasis. Emollients and moisturizers may help in improving barrier function and retain the hydration of stratum corneum. Topical agents used are coal tar, dithranol, corticosteroids, vitamin D analog, and retinoids.

  • The drug of choice is methotrexate and should be used as long as it remains effective
  • Cyclosporine can be used to induce a rapid clinical response but its use should be intermittent.
  • Other used options - retinoids, hydroxyurea are possible options. Routine blood, liver functions, and renal functions should be monitored in patients on systemic therapy.
  • Phototherapy includes PUVA therapy which combines psoralen with exposure to ultraviolet light (UVA), as well as NBUVB (Narrowband UVB light) with a range of 311 nanometers to 313 nanometers.
  • Biological can be used if patient fails to respond adequately to two front line drugs
  • Oral steroids like prednisolone not used in psoriasis. Only indication is Impetigo herpetiformis (pustular psoriasis of pregnancy)

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 152

questions.text: A farmer presented with lesion as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous disease of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, which sometimes involves muscle, bone, and neighbouring organs.

It is characterized by painless swelling, sinuses, pus discharge.

Mycetoma is produced by the introduction of microorganisms (bacteria or fungi) via localized trauma to the skin with thorns, wood splinters, or implantation with solid objects.

It typically affects the lower extremities. The hand is the next most common location

Mycetoma predominately occurs in farm workers

Mycetoma infection can be caused by fungi or bacteria. When caused by fungi, it is referred to as mycotic mycetoma or eumycetoma. When it is caused by bacteria, it usually involves infection by the actinomycetes group; such cases are called actinomycotic mycetoma or actinomycetoma

Mycetoma is characterized by the formation of grains, which contain aggregates of the causative organisms that may be discharged onto the skin surface through multiple sinuses. The characteristic color of the grains can assist in the identification of the specific etiologic agent.

Eumycetoma is mainly caused by Madurella mycetomatis, which produces 70% of all eumycetoma cases globally.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1348

questions.text: Identify the morphology of the lesion
questions.solution:
The image shows 3 concentric rings - target lesion or bulls eye lesion. This is also called as Iris lesion and that’s the answer. Classically seen in erythema multiforme


ANNULAR - Ring-like arrangement.

  • ARCUATE - Half-moon or arc shaped....
  • CIRCINATE - Circular or ringlike in shape.
  • COALESCING - Fusing of originally separate parts.

CONFLUENT - Joining or running together.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1-6

choices.text: Immunohistochemistry for clonal rearrangement of the T-cell receptor genes.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents with the erythematous scaly skin lesions on the trunk since 4-5 years. A skin biopsy was done and the findings are shown below. Which further test will help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Primary cutaneous lymphomas are the second most common extranodal non-Hodgkin Lymphomas. They may be of either T cell, B cell, or NK cell origin.

Cutaneous T Cell lymphomas (CTCL), Mycosis fungoides is the most common type of CTCL. It is a cutaneous lymphoma that originates in the peripheral epidermotropic T-cells, specifically the memory T-cells (CD45RO+).

It is more common in adults over 50 years of age,

Chronic indolent course, fatal disease

Mycosis fungoides tumor cells are characterized by epidermotropic peripheral T lymphocytes whose phenotype is CD2+, CD3+, CD4+, and CD5+.

Clinically - 3 stages

Patch stage: The earliest lesion seen in mycosis fungoides is an erythematous, or brownish scaly patch, which may show slight atrophy. Single or multiple lesions of variable diameters and locations develop, often in covered areas and particularly in the gluteal region and on the proximal thighs

Plaque stage:; In the plaque stage, lesions now appear larger with evident infiltration, along with the appearance of new lesions. Traised, well-defined edges and asymmetrical distribution. Tumor stage: In the tumor stage, erythematous-purplish papules or nodules of larger diameter are seen.

The frequency of lymph nodal or visceral dissemination increases as the lesions progress from the patch stage to the plaque stage and finally the tumor stage.

Sezary syndrome is the final end stage and is characterized by a triad of manifestations: erythroderma with pruritus, lymphadenopathy, and atypical circulating lymphocytes (referred to as Sezary or Lutzner cells). The syndrome is understood as a leukemic phase of T-cell cutaneous lymphoma.

HPE - Intra-epidermal lymphocytic Pautriers microabscess, cutaneous epidermotropism

Treatment

the main goals of therapy are long-term disease control, prompt symptom relief, and management of life-threatening (aggressive) disease

Early stage - total skin electron beam therapy (TSEBT), treatment of choice

For more extensive disease, combinations of skin-directed therapies and systemic therapies are used. The various systemic options available include methotrexate, bexarotene, targeted immunotherapy (such as alemtuzumab), polychemotherapy, etc

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 2132

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of endogenous eczema?
questions.solution:
Etiological Classification of Eczema

Endogenous eczema:

Seborrheic dermatitis

Nummular/Discoid dermatitis

Lichen simplex chronicus

Pityriasis alba

Stasis dermatitis

Atopic dermatitis

Pompholyx

Exogenous eczema:

  • Contact/ Irritant dermatitis
  • Allergic dermatitis
  • Photodermatitis
  • Radiation dermatitis
  • Infective dermatitis
  • Combined eczema:

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 208

questions.text: A male child born to non-consanguineous couplepresented with the following clinical picture. Similar lesions present in previous child and he died within few weeks of birth. Which investigation will help to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Congenital Epidermolysis bullosa. The IOC is electron microscopy. DIF and Tzank smear will be negative as this is not an immunobullous disease nd there is no acantholysis. Skin biopsy is inconclusive.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 541

questions.text: 70 year old man presented with lesion on the face, with history of bleeding when he scratches the lesion. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A shiny well-ill defined plaque with rolled up borders and a central erosion which may bleed on touch/scratching - BCC

Most common skin malignancy

Due to sun exposure

No premalignant lesion

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1884

questions.text: A patient presented with a white lesion on the side of the tongue, as shown in the image. What is the next investigation that should be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Oral hairy leukoplakia, caused by due to Epstein-Barr virus

The image shows a white plaque on side of tongue, with feathery margins and a corrugated surface. The plaque cannot be scraped off, which differentiates it from oral candidiasis.

This is usually an asymptomatic disease.

In a patient of HIV, it usually indicative of fairly advanced immunologic decline, generally occurring in patients with less than 300 CD4+ T cells per microliter.

It responds to HAART.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1370

choices.text: Mild lymphocytic infiltrate with presence of yeast on skin surface

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy from bihar presents with lesions on the face. The lesion showed slight scaling, rest of the examination was normal and doctor on duty did a skin biopsy from the lesion. The most likely findings in the report will be:
questions.solution:
Multiple hypopigmented scaly macules on face - Palba

Intraepidermal intercellular edema - spongiosis, seen in P.alba

Periappendegeal and perineural lymphocytic infiltrate - Indeterminate hansens (single hypopigmented macule with normal sensation, slight atrophy and no scaling.

Absent melanocytes in the epidermis - vitiligo

Mild lymphocytic infiltrate with presence of yeast on skin surface - pityriasis versicolor

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1104

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient presented with severe diffuse hair fall since last 1 month. She had an acute illness comprising of high fever and sore throat with anosmia 4 months back. She very anxious that all her hair will fall. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Severe physical stress, such as going through childbirth, surgery, or suffering a serious illness may precipitate a type of hair loss
  • The patient here seems to have suffered from covid
  • Stress forces large numbers of follicles to enter the resting phase(telogen), and after a 3-4 months, hair will fall out
  • Acute telogen effluvium is related do stressful events, and is self limiting.
  • No treatment needed

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1169

questions.text: A patient with hyperpigmented warty papules on the face and neck presents with nail findings as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Keratosis follicularis, also known as Darier disease (DD) autosomal dominantly inherited genodermatosis

Mutations in the gene ATP2A2

The lesions may first appear as skin-colored or yellow-brown papules with a greasy, warty texture. These lesions are especially common in seborrheic areas such as the forehead, scalp, margin of the scalp, nasolabial folds, ears, chest, and back

Nail changes in keratosis follicularis (Darier disease) provide important diagnostic clues. A sandwich of red and white longitudinal bands, often with a V-shaped nick at the free margin of the nail, is the most pathognomonic nail finding.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 950

questions.text: The image below represents :
questions.solution:
Fordyce's spot represents ectopic sebaceous glands on lips (most common site) and oral mucosa. They may also appear on vulva and penis, they are not associated with hair follicles (In contrast to normal sebaceous glands which have their ducts in hair follicles). Fordyce's spot is totally benign condition which occurs in normal people. It is characterized by discrete, pin-head sized superficial, light or yellow milium-like, maculo-papular lesions in mucous membrane of lips (especially vermilion portion), and sometimes buccal mucosa.

The condition usually appears at puberty and is more common in males.

As the condition is asymptomatic, no treatment is required, other than reassurance.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 584

questions.text: A 14 year old boy presents with some lesions on the toenails. he also has history of intractable seizures. What is the drug that should not be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image depicts - koenons tumor, also called as periungual fibromas. These are seen in tuberous sclerosis

Manifestation of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex

  • Seizures
  • Mental retardation
  • Retinal & optic nerve hamartomas
  • Achromic retinal patches
  • Involvement of skull, spine and pelvis
  • Dental pits
  • Tumors of heart (rhabdomyomas)

Reddish papules on face - adenoma sebaceoum

Periungual fibroms, also called as koenons tumors

Treatment

The main complication of TSC requiring long-term medical therapy is epilepsy. Antiepileptic medications (AEDs) are the mainstay of therapy for patients with TSC. Vigabatrin is the drug of first choice for children with TSC and infantile spasms. Topiramate, lamotrigine , valproate, and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)/steroids are also useful.

Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, and phenytoin may cause exacerbation of seizures, particularly in younger children and infants,

Everolimus tablets and tablets for suspension (Afinitor and Afintiro Disperz) are approved in the US for SEGAs, partial-onset seizures associated with tuberous sclerosis. Afinitor is also approved in adults with TSC-associated renal angiomyolipoma, not requiring immediate surgery.

Facial angiofibromas - Laser therapy, topical rapamycin

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 997

questions.text: What is the most common underlying malignancy seen in the following skin condition?
questions.solution:
Acanthosis nigricans is a velvety, darkening of the skin that usually occurs in intertriginous areas. This hyperpigmentation has poorly defined borders, usually occurs in skin fold areas, such as the back of the neck, axilla, and groin, and may include thickening of the skin.

Etiology

  • Increased circulating insulin that activates IGF-1 which may lead to keratinocyte and dermal fibroblast proliferation.
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Medications associated Acanthosis nigricans - nicotinic acid, systemic glucocorticoids, combined oral contraceptive pill, growth hormone therapy,
  • Hyperandrogenemia,PCOD

Malignant Acanthosis nigricans syndrome: Is associated with gastrointestinal adenocarcinomas. Malignancy-associated acanthosis nigricans usually has a rapid onset and is accompanied by skin tags, multiple seborrheic keratoses (sign of Leser-Trelat), or tripe palms.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 822

choices.text: More common in people with history of Atopy
They are painful but not pruritic
'Sago grain' seen on palms and sides of hand
Topical corticosteroids can be used for this condition

questions.text: The following are true about the condition given in the image except____
questions.solution:
Diagnosis - Pompholyx

Dyshidrotic eczema, also termed pompholyx, is a type of endogenous eczema

  • Symmetrical crops of clear vesicles and/or bullae (blisters)
  • Intensely pruritic (itchy)
  • Typically present on the palms and soles, as well as the lateral aspects of fingers and toes
  • Deep-seated vesicles with a tapiocalike / sago grain appearance

First-line treatment includes high-strength topical steroids

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 276

choices.text: Most likely due to the drug reaction
Histopathology shows basal cell degeneration and civatte bodies
Target lesions are the special lesions noted

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presented with eruption on the lips since 2 days, on treatment and now he has developed ring like lesions on palms and soles. Which of these statements is false for the palmoplantar lesions?
questions.solution:
Lips - grouped vesicles on lip margin s/o herpes labialis

Ring like lesions on acral areas like palms and soles s/o erythema multiforme. HSV infections are most common infectious cause of EM

Erythema multiforme (EM) is a cutaneous and mucosal hypersensitivity reaction with characteristic lesions in target triggered by certain antigenic stimuli.

The etiology of EM is dominated by Herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 and 2 infections and Mycoplasma pneumoniae, but many other viral, fungal and bacterial infections have been implicated. Malignancies like leukaemia, CTDs may also cause it

Drugs associated with EM include antibiotics like penicillins, cephalosporins, macrolides, sulfonamides, anti tuberculoid agents, antipyretics and many others. In some patients contact with heavy metals, herbal agents, topical therapies and poison ivy can trigger EM

Most lesions appear in 48-72 hours and favor the extremities

Clinically, the typical lesion of the EM is the target lesion, described as a rounded lesion that is regular with three concentric circles and a well-defined border. The peripheral ring is erythematous, sometimes microvesicular; the middle zone is often clearer, oedematous, and palpable, and the center is erythematous, covered by a blister.

Mucosal lesions are common, mostly in the mouth, but also in the genital and ocular mucous membranes

A punch biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis of EM The classic lesion will reveal a vacuolar interface dermatitis with marked infiltration with lymphocytes along the dermoepidermal junction

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 332

questions.text: A 8 month old infant developed multiple itchy, eczematous, exudative lesions on the body since 2 weeks. Similar lesions are also seen in elder brother. the most probable diagnosis is __
questions.solution:
Typical manifestations of scabies in infants are different from adults. With respect to scabies, infants are more likely to develop vesicles, pustules, and crusting than older children or adults

In addition, the face and scalp area may also be involved, which are usually spared in older children and adults.

The combination of a pruritic eruption with characteristic manifestations, and family involvement are usually sufficient to establish the diagnosis

Treatment consists of application of 5% permethrin cream at bedtime to all skin surfaces in infants and from the neck down in older family members; it should be washed off after 8~14 hours.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1503

questions.text: A patient presents with the following lesion. What will be the therapy given?
questions.solution:
Disease - lupus vulgaris

Reddish brown fleshy plaque with scarring in centre and active serpiginous margins

Diascopy shows golden yellow apple jelly nodules

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1307

questions.text: A 22 yr Male Developed Pigmentation over upper chest for the last 2 years as shown in image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Becker's nevusis a skin disorder predominantly affecting males.
  • more often shows up around puberty. It generally first appears as an irregular pigmentation (melanosisor hyperpigmentation) on the torso or upper arm (though other areas of the body can be affected), and gradually enlarges irregularly, becoming thickened and often hairy (hypertrichosis). The nevus is due to an overgrowth of the epidermis, pigment cells (melanocytes), and hair follicles. It is an androgen responsive tumor
  • Treatment:- As Becker's nevus is considered a benign lesion, treatment is generally not necessary except for cosmetic purposes.Q switched NDYAG laser can be used

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1956

questions.text: A child has rash on arms as shown. He also gives history of abdominal pain and cramping on eating sea food.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Atopic dermatitis(AD), also known as atopic eczema. It results in itchy, red, swollen, and cracked skin. Clear fluid may come from the affected areas, which often thicken over time.
  • The condition typically starts in childhood with changing severity over the years. In children under one year of age much of the body may be affected. As children get older, the back of the knees and front of the elbows are the most common areas affected.
  • In adults the hands and feet are the most commonly affected areas. Many people with atopic dermatitis develop hay feveror asthma.
  • The cause is unknown but believed to involve genetics, immune systemdysfunction, environmental exposures, and difficulties with the permeability of the skin
  • The diagnosis is typically based on the signs and symptoms - hanifin and rajka criteria
  • Treatment involves avoiding things that make the condition worse, daily bathing with application of a moisturising creamafterwards, applying steroid creams when flares occur, and medications to help with itchiness. Phototherapy may be useful in some people.Antibiotics (either by mouth or topically) may be needed if a bacterial infection develops.Dietary changes are only needed if food allergies are suspected.
  • AD commonly occurs on the eyelids where signs such as Dennie-Morgan infraorbital fold, infra-auricular fissure, periorbital pigmentation can be seen.Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation on the neck gives the classic 'dirty neck' appearance. Lichenification, excoriation and erosion or crusting on the trunk may indicate secondary infection. Flexural distribution with ill-defined edges with or without hyperlinearily on the wrist, finger knuckles, ankle, feet and hand are also commonly seen.
  • Many people with AD have a family history of atopy. Atopy is an immediate-onset allergic reaction (type 1 hypersensitivity reaction) that manifests as asthma, food allergies, AD or hay fever.The pathophysiology may involve a mixture of type I and type IV-like hypersensitivity reactions.
  • UK Diagnostic criteria

Medication:- Topical corticosteroids, such as hydrocortisone have proven themselves effective in managing AD.If topical corticosteroids and moisturisers fail, short-term treatment with topical calcineurin inhibitors like tacrolimus or pimecrolimus may be tried.Alternatively systemic immunosuppressants may be tried such as ciclosporin, methotrexate, interferon gamma-1b, mycophenolate mofetil and azathioprine.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 212

questions.text: A patient gets such lesions while doing exercising and on exposure to sunlight. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Cholinergic urticaria is one of the physical urticarias brought on by a physical stimulus. Although this stimulus might be considered to be heat, the actual precipitating cause is sweating.

An increase in core body temperature may trigger cholinergic urticaria; s

Cholinergic urticaria appears rather rapidly, usually within a few minutes after the onset of sweating, and lasts from a half hour to an hour or more

exercise is the most common precipitating event for cholinergic urticaria, but any stimulus that causes sweating, including elevated environmental temperature, hot food, sauna baths, immersion in hot water, gustatory stimuli, emotional stress, and hemodialysis,

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 307

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with asymptomatic lesions on the trunk as shown in the picture. The histopathological report shows perifollicular granulomas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tuberculids are a group of skin conditions associated with an underlying or silent focus of TB. Conditions in this group include: papulonecrotic tuberculid, LS, erythema induratum of Bazin, and erythema nodosum.

Lichen scrofulosorum (LS) also known as tuberculosis (TB) cutis lichenoides, is a rare tuberculid that presents as a lichenoid eruption of minute papules in children and adolescents with TB. The lesions are usually asymptomatic, closely grouped, skin-colored to reddish-brown papules, often perifollicular, and are mainly found on the abdomen, chest, back, and proximal parts of the limbs. The eruption is usually associated with a strongly positive tuberculin reaction

Histology shows non-caseating, epithelioid cell granulomas in upper dermis and around dermal appendages. Tubercle bacilli are almost never seen in the histology specimen,

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition. Pg No. 1308
